question1.title: 1.1. Is there potential for confounding of the effect of intervention in this study?

question2.title: 1.2. Was the analysis based on splitting participants' follow-up time according to intervention received?

question3.title: 1.3. Were intervention discontinuations or switches likely to be related to factors that are prognostic for the outcome?

question4.title: 1.4. Did the authors use an appropriate analysis method that controlled for all the important confounding domains?

question5.title: 1.5 Were confounding domains that were controlled for measured validly and reliably by the variables available in this study?

question6.title: 1.6. Did the authors control for any post- intervention variables that could have been affected by the intervention?

question17.title: 1.7. Did the authors use an appropriate analysis method that controlled for all the important confounding domains and for time-varying confounding?

question18.title: 1.8. Were confounding domains that were controlled for measured validly and reliably by the variables available in this study?

question1.title: 2.1. Was selection of participants into the study (or into the analysis) based on participant characteristics observed after  the start of intervention?

question2.title: 2.2. Were the post- intervention variables that influenced selection likely to be associated with intervention?

question3.title: 2.3. Were the post-intervention variables that influenced selection likely to be influenced by the outcome or a cause of the outcome?

question4.title: 2.4 Do start of follow-up and start of intervention coincide for most participants?

question5.title: 2.5.Were adjustment techniques used that are likely to correct for the presence of selection biases?

question2.title: 3.2 Was the information used to define intervention groups recorded at the start of the intervention?

question3.title: 3.3 Could classification of intervention status have been affected by knowledge of the outcome or risk of the outcome?

question4.title: 3.4 Were some aspects of intervention status assignments determined retrospectively?

question5.title: 3.5 An extremely high amount of intervention status misclassification?

question1.title: 4.1. Were there deviations from the intended intervention beyond what would be expected in usual practice?

question2.title: 4.2 Were these deviations from intended intervention unbalanced between groups and likely to have affected the outcome?

question3.title: 4.3 Were important co-interventions balanced across intervention groups?

question4.title: 4.4. Was the intervention implemented successfully for most participants?

question5.title: 4.5. Did study participants adhere to the assigned intervention regimen?

question6.title: 4.6. Was an appropriate analysis used to estimate the effect of starting and adhering to the intervention?

question7.title: 4.7. Did this occur at high intensity?

question1.title: 5.1 Were outcome data available for all, or nearly all, participants?

question2.title: 5.2 Were participants excluded due to missing data on intervention status?

question3.title: 5.3 Were participants excluded due to missing data on other variables needed for the analysis?

question4.title: 5.4 Are the proportion of participants and reasons for missing data similar across interventions?

question5.title: 5.5. Is there evidence that results were robust to the presence of missing data?

question6.title: 5.6. Did this occur at high intensity?

question7.title: 5.7. Were there critical differences between interventions in participants with missing data and were the missing data not, or could not, be addressed through appropriate analysis?

question1.title: 6.1 Could the outcome measure have been influenced by knowledge of the intervention received?

question2.title: 6.2 Were outcome assessors aware of the intervention received by study participants?

question3.title: 6.3 Were the methods of outcome assessment comparable across intervention groups?

question4.title: 6.4 Were any systematic errors in measurement of the outcome related to intervention received?

question5.title: 6.5 Did this occur at high intensity?

question6.title: 6.6 Were the outcome assessment methods so different that they cannot be reasonably compared between intervention groups?

question1.title: 7.1 Is the reported effect estimate likely to be selected, on the basis of the results, from multiple outcome measurements within the outcome domain?

question2.title: 7.2 Is the reported effect estimate likely to be selected, on the basis of the results, from multiple analyses of the intervention-outcome relationship?

question3.title: 7.3 Is the reported effect estimate likely to be selected, on the basis of the results, from different subgroups?

question4.title: 7.4 Did this occur at high intensity?

question5.title: 7.5 The unreported results are likely to be substantially different from the reported results?
